posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14625234
Yamnaya and proto CW are part of same early PIE community ~4500-4000BC with all the major haplogroups present (R1a-m417, R1b-m269, I2, among a few others). They all share roughly the same autosomal DNA.
R-z2103 Yamnaya-proper expands from within this community and dominates the lineages of the steppe zone, but this founder effect doesn't reach all PIE speakers, especially those in or closer to the forest steppe zone.

That's probably the most plausible explanation for why we keep finding different lineages in non-Yamnaya contexts.
CWC shows much more hg diversity than Yamnaya. They have R-L151, M417, but there is also singleton Q1b, R-V1636, and R-Z2103 samples in CW. Yamnaya so far only has z2103 and I2.

To expand on my statement that the Native Balkan population was much smaller than the Slavic population:

The number of Native Balkan people was heavily reduced in the centuries prior to the Slavic migration, raids from Huns, and the Justinian plague caused widespread death in all rural, mountainous and urban areas of the Balkans, and made the area extremely sparsely populated, with many people fleeing into fortified areas.

We see that when the Slavs began migrating, that they themselves decreased this population, which was small to begin with, even further. Thus the Native Illyrians and others could not leave a large genetic impact on the Slavs, and this is why they were assimilated, because they were outnumbered heavily by them.

National Socialism was not a conservative ideology.

>The first is that Hitler saw himself, accurately, as a revolutionary. Clearly it was a revolution of a different kind than that aimed at by Marxists, but it was still politics of a revolutionary kind and as such clearly distinct from the politics of the so-called bourgeois parties (liberals, social democrats, and Christian democrats) and also the conservatives and conventional nationalists. Zitelmann demonstrates that Hitler himself made this distinction, clearly and explicitly differentiating himself from the conservatives and putting the Nazi party, the Communists, and the Italian Fascists as rivals but fellow revolutionary movements, opposed to the constitutional politics of the bourgeois parties. He saw himself as a revolutionary because the political project he envisioned was one of fundamental transformation, a radical reshaping of the German social order, economy, and society. His politics was therefore total—encompassing every area of life, in the same way as communism—and he argued explicitly that this derived from its being a comprehensive weltanschauung (world view). This he explicitly contrasted to the limited and rule bound politics of liberalism and social and Christian democracy, which meant that it was conducted in a different way, one neither bound nor limited by law. The last aspect of this revolutionary approach was that the transformation of society it aimed at involved novelty and the creation of something new and unprecedented. This went along with a fascination, shared by most leading Nazis, with technology and modernism. This was all in marked contrast to the politics of radical reactionaries, such as the so-called conservative Maurras revolutionaries in Germany, and the Action Française in France, who looked to a reactionary politics of restoration and counter-revolution.

DINDIA MACOLNIA FILEAI DEDIT

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Wooden statuette sculpted by the natives of Rapa Nui.

These statues are called moai-miro by the natives and are known in literature as “ribbed images.” Usually they represent a naked male figure about a foot in length, carved of a solid dark wood, toto-miro (Edwardsia). Their general aspect is of a creature reduced by long suffering and starvation to skin and bones. The drawn face shows prominent cheek bones and deeply sunken eyes made by the insertion of bone and obsidian. The ribs, collar and shoulder bones, vertebrae, and pelvis jut out through the thin covering of skin. The nose is strongly aquiline; the mouth is grinning; the ears have very long artificially extended lobes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One of the two golden cups from Vapheio, Greece. 15th century BC


On one, with three scenes, a cow is used to lure a bull; they mate, and a rear leg is then roped; this is sometimes called the "Peaceful Cup" or the "Quiet Cup". In the other, the "Violent Cup", bulls are stampeded into nets, although one seems to escape, shoving catchers aside. The so-called "Violent Cup", showing netting of bulls, bears a remarkable resemblance to the description of the beginning of the ritual of consecration for the laws of Atlantis described in Plato's dialogue Critias, where bulls are captured for sacrifice, using no iron tools or weapons.

posts.com:
Modern Japanese are mostly exclusively an genetically East Asian population. The only group of Japanese ethnicities that have some ANE components are the Ainu of Hokkaido at ~14%, from Hokkaido Jōmon at approximately 21%. But they make up only about 25,000 people today.


In contrast, Native Americans have between 15% to 30%. ANE is its own branch, descending from West-Eurasian UP, deeply related to Europeans.

One of the noteworthy influences of this rather low amount are however gene alleles associated with facial features commonly found in Europeans among the Ainu. At least among some Ainu, as the Ainu formed from Hokkaido Jōmon, Okhotsk people and Satsumon people.

Hokkaido Jōmon themselves formed from Upper-Paleolithic groups of Northern Eurasia and East Asian-related groups from Honshu.


Conclusion:

Japanese people have slightly more ANE ancestry, samplified by the Yana sample of northern Siberia, than Han-Chinese or Koreans, however Japanese are closest to Koreans and other East Asians, the ANE (deeply European-related) component is minor. However it is the reason why some Japanese, especially some Ainu, have an appearance similar to Europeans or certain Native Americans.

>Garry Wills makes the case that there are actually four political parties in the United States. One of the many times when Wills inspired me to rethink, and reevaluate my own thoughts about the political process.

>”There are two presidential parties (Democrat and Republican), which address themselves to the nation as a whole, fashioning an inclusive philosophy of government and putting it up for debate every four years. But there are also two congressional parties (Democrat and Republican) composed of disparate local types running in staggered elections on local issues. Not only does Congress hamper the President; but each congressional party, controlling as it does the day-to-day ‘grass roots’ machinery, keeps its own presidential party from living up to that high vision created when platform-drafting time comes around.”

>Even when Congress is of the same party as the President it is still difficult in this country to achieve any comprehensive change because ultimately the agendas of the individuals, the pork for votes concept, will undermine the will of the President.

>Wills talks about the anti-intellectual movement in this country with most of the criticism coming from the Right. He quotes Spiro T. Agnew who served as Vice President under Nixon until an investigation for bribery, extortion, tax fraud, and conspiracy charges forced him to resign.

>That authoritarian strain is something Wills detects as existing within the United States' citizenry from the very beginning, an obedience to authority—whether scriptural, political, communal, cultural, or familial—that abrades against the freedom championed as the engine of the various markets that make-up the national character. And this very freedom—being what Americans deemed to set them above realms not so constituted, the source of the fuel that empowered the self-made man, the earner, the runner, the idea advocate, the self-determined realm—was severely called into question by the time of Vietnam: for not only were the elections that Americans were championing, and dying for, in Southeast Asia failing in the face of conflict, but those that took place at home produced no better an executive entity than Richard Nixon, a man who inspired little enthusiasm and had risen from the ashes of successive political failures at the opening of the decade.

>And so we arrive back at Nixon. He is, properly, the central locus of the book, the figure, so ill at ease with his chosen profession, whose unwavering devotion to all of the tenets that constitute the various Liberal markets brought under the authorial microscope marked him as the ideal representative of the resentment-bound self-made man that formed the Silent Majority and made the rise of a slick and crafty rabble-rouser like Wallace possible; made him the perfect representative with which to diminish the occupancy of the White House and starkly limn the problems endemic to the American conception of Liberalism heading into the latter stages of the twentieth century.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>I felt that Wills nailed down far more of the inner makeup of Nixon, what made this tormented but undeniably brilliant man tick, than Perlstein managed in far more pages; in particular, the chapter on the infamous Checkers Speech is just perfectly done—highlighting Nixon's courage, political instincts, hard work, and aggressiveness in pursuit of his ambition in perfect balance with his continuous humiliation, belittling slights from the elite classes, shiftiness and abject kowtowing to those same forces in the name of that same ambition. It is impossible to read Nixon Agonistes—an exquisitely apt title, that—without a sense of sympathy and understanding for that man, indeed for all introverts and grinders who must endure much suffering, many slings and arrows on the course of the racetrack the country demands that they run. He was never a particularly bad man, but rather one whose hard and lengthy road to the top must perforce have seared the very soul that such gains were not achieved as something for nothing—and, in the process, curdled that spirit with the gnomic deformations of resentment, rage, bitterness, and paranoia at what was demanded of one both by the silver spoon Franklins looking down upon you from above and the minorities and underclass scrabbling up desperately and insolently from below.

[...]

>It amazes me how much a perceptive mind could induce about America from the unattractive character traits of one of its least-heralded twentieth century presidents—that this very contender would prove such a symbolic exemplar of the class writhing under the whiplash of demanded and unfolding changes. Tricky Dick, then, was America: and that's as alarming as it is astounding.

>Per Wills, the long march to Nixon began at the turn of the 20th century as Woodrow Wilson and a succession of free market thinkers ratcheted up the liberal -- yes, I said liberal -- philosophy of individualism that gave rise to the robber barons of the previous century. It was a mode of thought that guided not only the economic life of the country, but its spiritual as well, making work and enterprise a religious endeavor. Morality could be measured by material success. Virtue lead to hard work which lead to success which lead to material wealth, rendering a man's inner morality visible. It was a very simple mantra, as Wills points out many times, straight out of Horatio Alger. Indeed, the rise of Nixon may well have been the last gasp of that mantra before its collapse into a coma where it has remained for some 40 years, twitching from time to time (Reagan, Gingrich, Tea Party), but never truly awakening before being knocked cold again by another damn recession.

>The lid came off the middle class in the '60s, and Nixon was the silent majority's answer to putting it back on ... Formerly invisible factions - blacks, women, college students -- were now visible, and the white working class were appalled at having their mores challenged in the streets by "non-earners." In 1968, George Wallace came along, and had his rather vocal following (is it me or is Ron Paul our modern day George Wallace?), scaring the bejesus out the GOP establishment who were afraid the Democrat/3rd Party man could swipe a good chunk of their base. Nixon, despite having a loser label on his head, having lost the 1960 Presidential race and the California Governor's race 2 years later ("You won't have Dick Nixon to kick around any more," he told a flock of reporters who had dogged him throughout the latter campaign), Nixon swooped-in to take the nomination in Miami from Nelson Rockefeller, Ronald Reagan, and George Romney.

>His grand thesis is that America is built on a type of classical liberalism (small-l) that included two distinct components: the ruthless social darwinism of the survival of the economic fittest; and the puritan view of business and capitalism as morally uplifting -- that is, free market liberalism and an ameliorative view of capitalism (which allows some room for the State). This type of liberalism was found in the views of both parties up until the 1920's - both in Wilson and in Hoover (TR's view was quite distinct). But under the pressure of the Great Depression, these two views split apart, one going to the Republicans, and one going to the Democrats. The half that went to the Republicans (laissez-faire) linked up with the authoritarian troglodytes of the JBS, southern whites, the religious loons (hence, the alliance of Milton Friendman with the loons and racists who rallied behind Barry Goldwater). The ameliorative part that went to the Democrats, did not become socialistic because the Dems retained their liberal (laissez-faire) attitude towards academia (free thought, freedom of dissent) and politics (decentralization).

>Nixon is (Wills wrote in 1969) misunderstood -- because he is being viewed through the lens of this Post-Depression "split". In fact, Nixon is a return to the classic liberalism of Woodrow Wilson and Hoover -- (much the the material Wills collects about Wilson, and about Nixon's admiration for Wilson is really persuasive and hard to gainsay).

>The problem is.... Wills continues.... that classical liberalism is essentially dead --. He (Wills) offers a skewering of its logical foundations (I've quoted one long passage in the comments section, though that is only a part of it) -- and because the complexity of modern society with its enforced interdependencies have rendered it really an anachronism.

>>14625142
>Life began on earth almost immediately, so life is probably fucking everywhere in the galaxy progressing at about the same pace as us.
There's a couple of issues with this reasoning.
First, there are reasons to believe that the early conditions of earth were more conducive to the emergence of life. For instance scientists have hypothesized that nuclear geysers were a necessary component in abiogenesis: https://researchoutreach.org/articles/origin-life-conditions-sparked-life-earth/
Secondly, life needed a long time to evolve intelligence and has a time constraint set by the sun to work within. If it happened much later it would've had a much harder time evolving intelligence before the sun burnt out.

Even then, 'almost immediately' on a 4.5 billion time scale means anything from a few hundred to 800 million years which is I think when the earliest fossil evidence dates to.
And even then, you still have to deal with the fermi paradox unless you think this is or is very close to the fastest possible development of civilization in the galaxy, as just a difference of a few million years would probably be enough for some of them to have colonized it by now. The sun/earth is also quite young compared to the galaxy/universe, so you'd also have to assume that it was uninhabitable for close to 10 billion years.

posts.sub: A private letter to Princess Victoria about meeting Karl Marx
posts.com:
by Sir Mountstuart Elphinstone Grant Duff

February 1, 1879

Madam,

Your Imperial Highness, when I last had the honour of seeing you, chanced to express some curiosity about Carl Marx and to ask me if I knew him. I resolved accordingly to take the first opportunity of making his acquaintance; but that opportunity did not arise till yesterday when I met him at luncheon and spent three hours in his company.

He is a short, rather small man with grey hair and beard which contrast strangely with a still dark moustache. The face is somewhat round, the forehead well shaped and filled up – the eye rather hard but the whole expression rather pleasant than not, by no means that of a gentleman who is in the habit of eating babies in their cradles – which is I daresay the view which the Police takes of him.

His talk was that of a well-informed, nay; learned man – much interested in Comparative Grammar which had led him into the Old Slavonic and other out of the way studies and was varied by many quaint turns and little bits of dry humour, as when speaking of Hesekiel's life of Prince Bismarck he always referred to it, by way of contrast to Dr. Busch's book, as the Old Testament.

It was all very positif slightly cynical – without any appearance of enthusiasm – interesting and often, as I thought, showing very correct ideas when he was conversing of the past or the present; but vague and unsatisfactory when he turned to the future.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
He looks, not unreasonably, for a great and not distant crash in Russia; thinks it will begin by reforms from above which the old bad edifice will not be able to bear and which will lead to its tumbling down altogether. As to what would take its place he had evidently no clear idea, except that for a long time Russia would be unable to exercise any influence in Europe.

Next he thinks that the movement will spread to Germany taking there the form of a revolt against the existing military system.

To my question "But how can you expect the army to rise against its commanders?" he replied – you forget that in Germany now the army and the Nation are nearly identical. These Socialists you hear about are trained soldiers like anybody else. You must not think of the standing army only. You must think of the Landwehr – and even in the standing army there is much discontent. Never was an army in which the severity of the discipline led to so many suicides. The step from shooting oneself to shooting one's officer is not long, and an example of the kind, once set, is soon followed.

But supposing I said the rulers of Europe came to an understanding amongst themselves for a reduction of armaments which might greatly relieve the burden on the people what would become of the Revolution which you expect it one day to bring about?

Ah, was his answer they can't do that. All sorts of fears and jealousies will make that impossible. The burden will grow worse and worse as science advances for the improvements in the Art of Destruction will keep pace with its advance and every year more and more will have to be devoted to costly engines of war. It is a vicious circle – there is no escape from it. But I said you have never yet had a serious popular rising unless there was really great misery. You have no idea, he rejoined, how terrible has been the crisis through which Germany has been passing in these last five years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well I said supposing that your Revolution has taken place and that you have your Republican form of Government – it is still a long long way to the realization of the special ideas of yourself and your friends. Doubtless he answered but all great movements are slow. It would merely be a step to better things as your Revolution of 1688 was – a mere stage on the road.

The above will give Your Imperial Highness a fair idea of the kind of ideas about the near future of Europe which are working in his mind.

They are too dreamy to be dangerous except just in so far as the situation with its mad expenditure on armaments is obviously and undoubtedly dangerous.

If however within the next decade the rulers of Europe have not found means of dealing with this evil without any warning from attempted revolution I for one shall despair of the future of humanity at least on this continent.

In the course of conversation Carl Marx spoke several times both of Your Imperial Highness and of the Crown Prince and invariably with due respect and propriety. Even in the case of eminent individuals of whom he by no means spoke with respect there was no trace of bitterness or savagery – plenty acrid and dissolvent criticism but nothing of the Marat tone.

Of the horrible things that have been connected with the International he spoke as any respectable man would have done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One thing which he mentioned showed the dangers to which exiles who have got a revolutionary name are exposed. The wretched man Nobiling, he had learned, had when in England intended to come to see him. If he had done so he said I should certainly have admitted him for he would have sent in his card as an employe of the Dresden Bureau of Statistics and as I occupy myself with Statistics it would have interested me to talk with him – What a pleasant position I should have been in he added if he had come to see me!

Altogether my impression of Marx, allowing for his being at the opposite pole of opinion from oneself, was not at all unfavourable and I would gladly meet him again. It will not be he who whether he wishes it or not will turn the world upside down.
https://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/bio/media/marx/79_01_31.htm

posts.com: At some point there would have been reform along the lines of federalization, which would have been opposed by the Hungarians (since they would lose their dual monarchy leverage) and possibly causing them to revolt. If the union survives that roadbump, then you gradually see the various minorities gain more political power at the expense of the primarily German elite, leading to more investment in the more rural Slavic parts of the empire. Most people would be multilingual, with German as the lingua franca across the empire. There would be both ethnic interest political parties and all-union parties (e.g. social democrats, Christian democrats, liberals). Assuming there's no Holocaust in this timeline, there's also a substantial Jewish population in most major cities. In real life, Jews were the strongest supporters of the imperial union because they were wary of ethno-nationalism, and the same would be true here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14621195
Everyone seems to assume A-H would have collapsed right after WW1 even if they had won, but in reality, most minorities within the Empire were quite satisfied with it, with the Serbs and Romanians being the only true exceptions. Emperor Karl was in favor of extensive federalization, with the goal of transforming the empire into a loose confederation with a unified market and foreign policy. The idea was very popular ever since the beginning of the 20th century, especially appealing to each ethnicity's upper classes, and I see little reason why it couldn't have been a success.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14625813
I said Noble Silence. The questions that Buddha did not answer because any answer leads to improper conclusion.
For example, asked by a certain sage if Buddha exists after death, or ceases to exist after death, Buddha remained silent. Why? To say "Yes" would affirm eternalism. Buddha did not affirm this. To say "No" would mean affirming nihilism. Buddha did not affirm this.
Why? Because Buddha taught that all phenomena are devoid of a self-nature. Thus, it cannot be said that he existed nor did not exist in the very moment, let alone after his death, as there is only not-self to begin with! Therefore, nothing to continue nor anything to cease!
Nothingness is as wrong-minded as Everythingness. The Middle Way is all that brings a remedy to the poisons of dukkha.
The reason Buddha did not answer these questions as well is because they do not resolve suffering, which is extreme and immediate, but instead simply lead to a thicket of views. This is in the analogy of the poisoned arrow from the Cula-Malunkyovada Sutta.

posts.sub: Does ‘Being On The Right Side Of History’ Even Exist?
posts.com: Yes/No and why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yes, "Being on the Right Side of History" does exist, but the concept is subjective and can vary depending on one's beliefs, values, and cultural background. The idea of being on the right side of history refers to aligning oneself with actions, values, and ideas that are considered to be ethical, moral, and just in the present moment, with the belief that they will be recognized and remembered as such in the future. However, the definition of what is considered right and just can change over time as societies evolve and perspectives shift. Therefore, the concept of being on the right side of history is always in flux and subjective.

I'm sorry but I don't think you know what idolatry is. In the context of the Hebrew Bible i.e. the ancient Near East, it was thought that the gods would actually come to inhabit the idols they represent, hence they were treated as living things and great care was taken to preserve them (Jeremiah 10:9). We can see this clearly in the story of Bel in Daniel 14:3-6 (which you Prots conveniently dropped because of your Satanism) where the Babylonians literally thought their idol of Bel was eating the food offered to him (spoiler: he wasn't't, the priests of Bel came in at night to deceive the people). When a neighboring tribe or nation conquered another, the idols of that nation would be carried off as a symbol that the god of that victor nation had defeated the god(s) of the losing nation (Isaiah 46:2). We see this in 1 Samuel 5:2 after the Philistines captured the Ark and set it before their idol Dagon not understanding the power that acted through it (1 Samuel 5:4-12). By the way, in your understanding of idolatry you should consider the Ark an idol, after all the priest on the Day of Atonement would offer incense and sprinkle blood before the mercy seat (Leviticus 16:13-15), which by the way was between statue of two Cherubim that God commanded the Israelites to make (Exodus 25:18), in a Temple that had been constructed with artwork (1 Kings 6:29). When Catholics bow before images we bow not to the actual image or statue but to what it represents, bowing is not always done as an act of adoration (it certainly constitutes part of that but is not the same as it) it can be a sign of simple respect or veneration, as when Jacob bowed seven times when coming to meet Esau (Genesis 33:3).

Chronology dude. Some kind of proto slavs must have been around somewhere for some time. Herodotus maybe mentions them as "forest scythians" which suggests they didn't in fact live in the steppe. The first explicit mentions of slavs show up 1000 years after Herodotus, with possibility that earlier on they were known to the ancients as Venedi and lived somewhere east of Vistula, which is more certain than the "forest scythians", but depending on your standard of evidence you may be sceptical, but again not really a steppe(to give you tl; dr Jordanes who is the one telling us Venedi=Slavs knows what he's talking about simply because he was a secretary of a gothic commander in eastern roman service, guarding the Danube at the very time slavs started to appear there, so in some likelihood he just had a chance to ask them who they are and where they came from, that being said, the venedi veneti, wenden etc. are something that shows up everywhere - Northern Wales, Iberia, Italy, Eastern Europe - may as well be unrelated and the Venedi Jordanes knows from Ptolemy and the Venedi he heard about from the slavs may be different people).

They didn't always live in the steppe belt. In fact their initial settlements in 6th century and later are always located in more hilly areas, indicating that their adaptation to being in a more of a "horse country" was to build outside of it on a micro scale. Once we have good sources on them outside of the Balkans(where again, they're not really living in the steppe) we see them having significant cavalry component in their armies, but that's already 10th century.

Mathieson et al. (2018) included a genetic analysis of eight males of the Globular Amphora culture. Three of them carried haplogroup I2a2a1b and a subclade of it; two carried I2a2; one carried I2; one carried BT and one carried CT.[5] According to admixture analysis they also had approximately 70% EEF ancestry and 30% WHG ancestry, some of them with negligible Eastern Hunter-Gatherer and Yamnaya traces.[6]

I2a1a2b-L621 is typical of the Slavic populations, being highest in Southeastern European regions of Bosnia-Herzegovina and South Croatia (>45%),[3][14][15] in Bosniaks (43.53-52.17%), Croats (37.7-69.8%), and Serbs (36.6-42%), because of which is often called "Dinaric".[16] It has the highest variance and also high concentration in Eastern Europe (Ukraine, Southeastern Poland, Belarus).[17]

>>14624658
>how God himself makes even his most faithful believers suffer for no reason whatsoever
Except that isn't the takeaway from this at all. We see that there is a reason, just Job doesn't know it. Also, even though Satan wants evil for Job, God means it for good, as with all things. For it says, "And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose." (Rom. 8:28).

>It is only when Job had experienced God firsthand that he truly believed
I don't think so. The Lord says this at the beginning of the book: "And the LORD said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil?" (Job 1:8)

Rather, what we see is Job standing steadfast in his belief despite the assumptions of his friends, however in attempting to defend himself he makes a challenge to God, and thus tries more to defend himself than God. This is what Elihu points out when he finally enters the picture in chapter 32-37. He points out how that, while Job's friends indeed were making wrong assumptions, Job himself was also going too far in certain things he said in response to their arguments. See chapter 32-37. After that, God Himself speaks to Job out of the whirlwind from chapter 38 to the end, which is in effect an answer to Job's request. Actually, having Elihu start the response to Job, before God Himself directly steps in, is part of the answer as well.

Job, as a result of hearing these things from God repents of asking/demanding God to give an answer to him as he did earlier. Yet the speech here is to all of us, not just Job.

We also find that nature itself is presented as a witness to the glory of God in these chapters, similar to other Scriptures. Psalm 19 for instance opens by saying, "The heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament sheweth his handywork." See also Romans 1:20, and many more passages.

posts.com: >Cædmon (/ˈkædmən, ˈkædmɒn/; fl. c. 657 – 684) is the earliest English poet whose name is known.[1] A Northumbrian cowherd who cared for the animals at the double monastery of Streonæshalch (now known as Whitby Abbey) during the abbacy of St. Hilda, he was originally ignorant of "the art of song" but learned to compose one night in the course of a dream, according to the 8th-century historian Bede. He later became a zealous monk and an accomplished and inspirational Christian poet.[2]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14625699
>According to Bede, Cædmon was a lay brother who cared for the animals at the monastery Streonæshalch (now known as Whitby Abbey). One evening, while the monks were feasting, singing, and playing a harp, Cædmon left early to sleep with the animals because he knew no songs. The impression clearly given by St. Bede is that he lacked the knowledge of how to compose the lyrics to songs. While asleep, he had a dream in which "someone" (quidam) approached him and asked him to sing principium creaturarum, "the beginning of created things." After first refusing to sing, Cædmon subsequently produced a short eulogistic poem praising God, the Creator of heaven and earth.

>Upon awakening the next morning, Caedmon remembered everything he had sung and added additional lines to his poem. He told his foreman about his dream and gift and was taken immediately to see the abbess, believed to be St Hilda of Whitby. The abbess and her counsellors asked Cædmon about his vision and, satisfied that it was a gift from God, gave him a new commission, this time for a poem based on "a passage of sacred history or doctrine", by way of a test. When Cædmon returned the next morning with the requested poem, he was invited to take monastic vows. The abbess ordered her scholars to teach Cædmon sacred history and doctrine, which after a night of thought, Bede records, Cædmon would turn into the most beautiful verse. According to Bede, Cædmon was responsible for a large number of splendid vernacular poetic texts on a variety of Christian topics.

>In the final week of the campaign, Stassen returned to anti-communism, the issue which had boosted his campaign to the forefront.[13] Stassen attacked Dewey for a "soft, coddling policy" on communism in the United States and challenged him to a direct debate on the issue—the first ever head-to-head radio debate between two presidential candidates.[14] Dewey accepted, and as the challenged party, chose the format, topic, and rules; the debate would be broadcast nationally on 900 stations from a quiet studio at KEX Portland. The single topic: "Shall the Communist Party be outlawed in the United States?"[14] The debate was heard by an estimated 40–80 million listeners throughout the country, one of the largest audiences in history.[14]

>During the debate, Stassen read credited his wartime service and world travels for his belief than an international Communist network demanded immediate, punitive response. Dewey responded with an extemporaneous criticism of the Mundt-Nixon Bill as a "grievous error," and pointed to the fact that Canada had banned communism but still hosted an international espionage ring in the Russian embassy.[14]

>In January of 1973—the same month that the Rolling Stones were banned from touring Japan due to prior drug convictions, the same month that a band called Kiss played its first gig in Queens, and the same month that a young New Jerseyan named Bruce Springsteen released his debut album on Columbia Records—Harper’s magazine published an essay by future Pulitzer Prize winner Margo Jefferson titled “Ripping Off Black Music.” The piece was partly a broad historical overview of white appropriations of black musical forms, from blackface minstrel pioneer T.D. Rice through the current day, and partly a more personal lament over what Jefferson, a black critic, had come to see as an endless cycle of cultural plunder. The article’s most striking moment arrived in its penultimate paragraph:

>The night Jimi died I dreamed this was the latest step in a plot being designed to eliminate blacks from rock music so that it may be recorded in history as a creation of whites. Future generations, my dream ran, will be taught that while rock may have had its beginnings among blacks, it had its true flowering among whites. The best black artists will thus be studied as remarkable primitives who unconsciously foreshadowed future developments.

Bluegrass, country, blues, rock and roll, all of them come from the central blend of Scots-Irish and West African, the Irish fiddle meeting the banjo, a combination unique to the South. Bluegrass is a blend of old school Appalachian folk or old time string music emphasising the off-beat (pretty directly Scottish and Irish, Scottish bagpipes and ole-time fiddlin) and West African rhythms and instrumentation (clawhammer banjo). Country music is much the same in origin throughout the American west, a blend of Irish, Scottish and English folk traditions with West African rhythms, repetitions and instrumentation, with some threads being influenced by Latin music like Mexican, norteño, mariachi and tejano. Bohemian polka has also had an influence in places like Texas. Western swing is like country-jazz, or jazz that became country. In the 1920s, the 'hillbilly' music scene around Atlanta saw the introduction of the Hawaiian steel guitar and ukelele, and that's when country music truly came into existence as a genre distinct from bluegrass, blues and other American folk music. You also had jug bands and, in Louisiana, French-influenced Cajun and Creole music which led to things like zydeco and had an influence in New Orleans, the birthplace of jazz.
You throw in the developments of Negro sprituals, gospel music, cakewalk/ragtime, New Orleans big band music, and you can piece together most of the history of American music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617762

Jazz is originally African American, and employed Black New Orleans and Cajun sounds, inspired by spirituals and hymns, also with the West African cross-rhythms and call-and-response style of work songs and field hollers, preserving the 'traditional sub-Saharan African harmony' of African drumming, but in other polyphonic styles after the Black Codes outlawed drumming by African slaves. There was also a Cuban habanera/contradanza influence. The big innovation in jazz was the jazz scale, which draws from common scales of Western European classical music (diatonic, whole-tone, octatonic, melodic minor modes), but allowing for the interpretation, repetition and improvisation central to jazz as a genre. Jazz was initially an urban phenomenon in the South - Dixieland jazz in New Orleans in the 1910s - but when the blues scale developed in the rural Deep South, it entered jazz and introduced the out-of-key "blue note" to an existing scale, notably the flat fifth addition to the minor pentatonic scale, and jazz was never the same again. New Orleans jazz travelled north to Chicago and New York with the First Great Migration in the 1910s, generation on generation. Cakewalk and ragtime developed on the way in places like St Louis, influenced by jazz, but when it reached New York it got sucked up into theatre music and Yiddish musical styles, which is the origin of Tin Pan Alley. After a generation, big band music was formed, and swing became the most popular American music genre for about 15 years (Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617789

Blues had been growing in the Deep South since the 19th century, arguably since the end of the Civil War. Initially, blues was literally just spirituals and slave songs, and many of the old blues standards are written in this style and come directly from those traditions. The lines are often sung following a pattern closer to rhythmic talk than to a melody, which is seen as something reflected in Igbo music. The four-beats-per-measure of the blues has been associated with the melodies of the Bambara people, and to a lesser degree, the Soninke people and Wolof people, but not as much of the Mandinka people. The original country blues coagulated in the Mississippi delta as Delta blues, which was heavily influenced by folk music. This is when country and blues were essentially bonded, and blues had a great effect on the birth of bluegrass. Robert Johnson was a master of the Delta blues, and was part of the transition from uncommercial to commercial blues, which saw it explode in popularity. As the Second Great Migration (starting in the 40s) saw Blacks coming out the Deep South, bringing the country blues to the Northern cities where jazz and swing were already dominating, the new synthesis and the popularisation of blues scales and chord progressions like the 12-bar-blues (most famous chord progression in popular music) began the birth of early rock and roll. One split off before rock and roll was 'rhythm and blues' and doo wop, which was more swing and big band oriented. Chuck Berry then took the aggressive guitar sound from electric blues and made rock and roll what it would eventually be.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14617793

Skiffle music was basically British blues, inspired by a combination of the blues and old Victorian music hall. When rock and roll and the new commercial genre of 'rhythm and blues' hit the Mersey and its skiffle bands in the 1950s, beat music was born, from which The Beatles emerged. Rhythm and blues and rock and roll spread across the Western world, influencing Caribbean music genres like calypso and nyabinghi which led to rocksteady, reggae and dub.
The rest of popular American music - r'n'b, soul, funk, hip hop, punk, metal - all came from descendants of the synthesis between the New Orleans jazz that spread to the Northern cities with the First Great Migration, the old-school American rural folk music like bluegrass, and the Southern Delta blues that exploded in popularity immediately following WW2.

Basically, without Africans, American music probably wouldn't have had A) the banjo, B) blues scale, or C) jazz polyphonic harmonies. These are all things that seem to have originated from different forms of West African music carried over by slaves. American music would still probably be incredibly unique and diverse, with many other influences, but a large portion would be fundamentally different. Perhaps there would be even more folk influence, in the style of blue grass, or more Latin and French influence (although Latin music is very African-influenced). It's also a high chance that Western art music/classical music and its scales and modes would still be very popular amongst the upper classes. If you want to imagine 20th century popular music without African Americans, imagine a more folk-like bluegrass without a banjo and without a blues scale, instead working on a traditional European classical scale like diatonic, whole-tone, etc. There also may have been more indigenous influence than in real life.

>>14618672

The violin predates Irish and Scottish fiddling by hundreds of years, but it was Scots-Irish immigrants in the 17th and 18th centuries who brought the to Appalachian mountains. These immigrants were usually dissenters - Ulster Scot Presbyterians who left due to the Confederate Wars, 17th and 18th century famines, the Penal Laws which disadvantaged non-Anglicans, or the absentee landlordism of the Anglo Protestant Ascendancy. Bluegrass fiddling is descended from Ulster/Donegal and Highland/Borders fiddling styles.
Although a fiddle is basically the same as a violin, fiddle music as a style means that there will be specific construction differences between a fiddle and a classical violin - fiddles will have flattened bridge tops and lower string action heights, and will often have steel strings. Fiddle music is also taught by ear rather than by written music, because it's folk. This is the kind of fiddle music that came to Appalachia, and also other rural parts of early colonial America, where English settlers also played fiddle music.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14622404
Jesus Christ.

Banjos were originally fretless and made from gourds with a skin head. Later people would start making them from grain measures, which is a nice wooden hoop of standard size that you can find lying around. These would have open backs. Minstrel players added metal tone rings to the hoops to help make them louder for playing crowded music halls. Resonator backs would even later be added for similar reason. Steel strings ditto. They also added frets because it makes it easier to play with stuff like complex chords, which weren't originally played on banjos.

Banjos were adapted over centuries, including very often by white people who brought banjos into the popular mainstream by way of minstrel theater. The banjos we know now, five strings, fretted, with a resonator back for bluegrass playing, are relatively modern 20th Century instruments given that banjos have existed in some form probably since the Atlantic slave trade opened.

The Depression destroyed record sales, but especially for jazz, blues and country. There was a golden decade between where the recording industry discovered southern folk derived music and the depression wiped it out. Before that, southern folkish type stuff was done by northern professional musicians in minstrel or hick mode, but the 20s marks the first time most of the American music being argued over on this thread made it onto records.

By the time the industry rebounded in the mid 30s, the music had changed. Blues and hillbilly became slicker, with a new generation who grew up on records and radio, and many of the older artists went back to being coal miners or sharecroppers, with a few lucky survivors enjoying a revival with the folk boom a few decades later. Jazz musicians either adopted to the new sound with bigger swing ensembles, or also faded away until rediscovered by trad jazz “mouldy figs”. The early years of the Great Depression, like WWII, mark a big “before and after” gap in American music.

The expression arose sometime during the later nineteenth century in the better brothels of New Orleans, which provided music and dancing as well as sex. The original Jazz band, according to Herbert Asbury's The Latin Quarter (1938), was the 'Spasm Band' made up of seven boys, aged twelve to fifteen, who first appeared in New Orleans about 1895. They advertised themselves as the "Razzy Dazzy Spasm Band."

In c.1900 (see Jazz Timeline) another band adopted the same billing for an appearance at the Haymarket dance hall, it is said the 'Spasms' loaded their pockets with rocks and dropped by to protest the infringement. This prompted the owner of the hall to repaint his advertising placards to read: "Razzy Dazzy Jazzy Band!" If the memories of Asbury's sources were correct (he talked to two surviving members of the 'Spasms') this represents the word's earliest-known appearance in print.

'Jazz' is not a bad word now, but almost certainly the etymology is of extremely low origin, referring to copulation before it was applied to music, dancing, and nonsense (i.e., all that Jazz). The vulgar word was in general currency in dance halls thirty years or more ago" (Clay Smith, Etude 9/24). "According to Raven I. McDavid Sr. of Greenville, S.C., the 1919 announcement of the first 'Jazz band' to play in Columbia, where he was then serving in the state legislature, inspired feelings of terror among the local Baptists such as what might have been aroused by a personal appearance of Yahweh. Until that time 'Jazz' had never been heard in the Palmetto States except as a verb meaning to copulate" (H. L. Mencken, The American Language Raven I. McDavid Jr. 1963). "She never stepped out of line once in all the years we been teamed up. I can't sell her on jazzing the chump now" (William Lindsay Gresham, Nightmare Alley 1946).

Storyville was the red-light district of New Orleans, Louisiana, from 1897 to 1917.

The District was established to restrict prostitution to one area of the city where authorities could monitor and regulate such activity. In the late 1890s, the New Orleans city government studied the legalized red light districts of northern German and Dutch ports and set up Storyville based on such models.

Establishments in Storyville ranged from cheap "cribs" to more expensive houses, up to a row of elegant mansions along Basin Street for well-heeled customers. New Orleans' cribs were 50-cent joints, whereas the more expensive establishments could cost up to $10. Black and white brothels coexisted in Storyville; but black men were barred from legally purchasing services in either black or white brothels.

At the creation of Storyville, black and white musicians were segregated. The red-light district first opened to African Americans who brought their musical background with them.

Musicians were hired by madams (owners of the brothel houses) to entertain clients within the mansion's parlors. These audiences tended to not be very critical

At the same time dance halls and saloons would hold the attention of their patrons with ragtime dance bands.

I think that arguments like this are a little too simple from Atheists, and that's why they normally don't change any minds.

While it is certainly confusing as to why a Personal God would "allow" things like this to happen, this stuff actually exists as a spectrum and not a binary.

What is really being asked in posts like this is "if God is real, then why are we mortal". Because we will all die some day, that's a given. Some of us will die earlier than others, and some of us will die more painfully than others, or less fulfilled than others. But no Atheist ever points to a 50-year old man dying of some silent-killer disease: even though the same premise holds that God is seemingly cruel for taking him at 50 when he could have taken him at 51, or 52, or 53, and so on. Instead, these posts are always about hideously deformed children, because it's foremost an emotional argument before it is a reasonable argument.

A more important question is to ask what happens to them after death. Most Christians would hold that if unbaptized then these babies either go to Hell or float around in limbo until they are saved. Now, not all Christians believe in limbo--it's not even taught as dogma in most churches I bet. However, Hell is also not to be confused with Dante's Inferno--there is no fire there, no brimstone, just a separation from God which is painful to the soul.

>>14621290
The UK could easily have suppressed the IRA if they'd actually started treating it like a military conflict rather than a policing matter. The question was: to what end?

Bernard Montgomery, a major who served in Ireland, wrote of the issue:

>My own view is that to win a war of this sort, you must be ruthless. Oliver Cromwell, or the Germans, would have settled it in a very short time. Nowadays public opinion precludes such methods, the nation would never allow it, and the politicians would lose their jobs if they sanctioned it. That being so, I consider that Lloyd George was right in what he did, if we had gone on we could probably have squashed the rebellion as a temporary measure, but it would have broken out again like an ulcer the moment we removed the troops. I think the rebels would probably [have] refused battles, and hidden their arms etc. until we had gone.

It was a particularly pointless war from the UK's viewpoint given that they had already been on the cusp of giving Ireland Home Rule just before the outbreak of WW1. An often overlooked fact is that Ireland didn't actually gain independence after the rather inaccurately named War of Independence - they remained a part of the British Empire with the King as their head of state. So really the settlement the British got after the war was barely more than what they had been going to give the Irish anyway. It wasn't until the 1940s that Ireland severed the last constitutional ties with the UK.

There was also the issue that, contrary to what a lot of people seem to think, Irish people could vote in UK parliamentary elections. Keeping Ireland in the union would have led to a sizeable Sinn Fein block in the British parliament, which would have been inconvenient for all concerned.

And all this aggravation would have been for a region that was economically worthless to the UK.

>>14621999
>peculiar tradition as the eunuch so widespread in eurasia
Harems. Pre-industrial people were absolutely obsessed with lineage, and particularly noble lineage. Europe "solved" this issue with monogamous marriage and prohibition on extra-marital sex via religion. This system worked okay (although it was far from perfect).

In the East, Kings and Princes kept huge harems with hundreds, if not thousands of women, and so those nobles had a vested interest in ensuring only their progeny was born from the harem. This meant staffing your palace with eunuchs who physically cannot produce offspring. Also there was the belief that eunuchs would not betray a ruler because they had no real stake in the game since they had no family. A Eunuch can't put his son on the throne if he betrays you or whatever. The problem with this line of thinking (as the Chinese found out the hard way) is that eunuchs can still be self serving and meddle with shit for their own gain even if they can't pass that wealth on.

Anyways, tl;dr, paternity/harem security and no competitive counselors/palace staff/ruling caste

>Harems. Pre-industrial people were absolutely obsessed with lineage, and particularly noble lineage.

Partly. Harems existed to perpetuate the enlargening of the royal/imperial clan AND its survival in a time before premodern maternity care where infant mortality was through the roof.

>Europe "solved" this issue with monogamous marriage

I wouldn't call succession wars thanks to marriage bullshit & a line of extinct dynasties as "solving" the problem. China & the East may have had problems with its Eunuchs and Harems but to their credit most succession crises are intradynastic affairs and palace plotting instead of drowning the whole country in succession wars. China even had like 2 succession wars in their entire history.

Europe's actual solution to the problem is divorcing the state from the dynasty (aka building a nation state and not giving a shit about the monarchy & their drama.)
